{{Infobox power station |name = Medupi Power Station |image = |image_caption = |location_map = South Africa |country = [[South Africa]] |locale = [[Lephalale]] |lat_d = 23|lat_m = 42|lat_s = |lat_NS = S |long_d = 27|long_m = 33|long_s = |long_EW = E |coordinates_type = type:landmark_region:ZA-LP |coordinates_display = title |owner = [[Eskom]] |status = Under construction |primary_fuel = [[Coal]] |conveyance = |combined_cycle = |generation_units = 6 Ã 798 [[Megawatt|MW]] |installed_capacity = none |max_planned_cap = 4,788 MW |average_annual_gen = |commissioned = 2012 |decommissioned = }} The '''Medupi Power Station''' is a new dry-cooled coal fired power station being built by [[Eskom]] near [[Lephalale]] in [[Limpopo]] province, [[South Africa]]. When completed, the power station will have six boilers each powering an 800 MW turbine, producing 4800 MW of power. This will be the largest dry-cooled coal fired power station in the world.<ref>www.eskom.co.za/content/NB%200002MedupiPowerStation.doc</ref> Contracts have been placed with [[Hitachi]] to supply the boilers and [[Alstom]] to provide the Steam turbines for this plant.<ref>http://www.tradeinvestsa.co.za/news/982506.htm</ref> At R33.6 Billion, these are the biggest contracts ever placed by Eskom. Super-critical boilers will be used to improve the efficiency of the power plant.<ref>http://www.engineeringnews.co.za/article/supercritical-boilers-to-improve-efficiency-at-medupi-2007-12-14</ref>
Medupi will be supplied by coal from [[Exxaro|Exxaroâs]] Grootegeluk coal mine, located to the north of the site. Eskom has placed a contract with Exxaro to supply 14.6 MT coal per year for 40 years.<ref>http://www.engineeringnews.co.za/article/medupi-project-on-track-for-scheduled-delivery-2008-12-05</ref> The first 800 MW unit is expected to be commissioned in early 2012, with the next units following at 9 month intervals. The power station is currently expected to cost R100 Billion.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/oilRpt/idUKLK4963152009012 | work=Reuters | deadurl=yes}} {{Dead link|date=September 2011|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref>
The building of the coal power station has attracted widespread criticism in South Africa.<ref>http://www.mg.co.za/article/2010-04-03-zille-says-anc-stands-to-make-r1bn-from-medupi</ref> Critics have accused the ANC led government of pushing the project forward because the political party holds a 25% stake in the venture and stands to make a profit close to 1 Billion rand on the deal.<ref>{{cite web|title=Opposition slams ANC 'about-turn' on Hitachi|url=http://www.mg.co.za/article/2010-04-14-opposition-slams-anc-aboutturn-on-hitachi|publisher=Mail & Guardian Online|accessdate=24 May 2010|date=14 April 2010}}</ref> Backers of the project argue that the plant is needed to supply vital electricity to South Africa over the long term.<ref>http://powerplants.einnews.com/login.php?redir=%2Fnews.php%3Fwid%3D287187525&n=12</ref> Some point out that effective management of coal supplies was what was really needed, rather than yet another environmentally unfriendly coal station.<ref>http://www.info.gov.za/otherdocs/2008/nationalresponse_sa_electricity1.pdf</ref> The approval of the World Bank loan drew criticism as a massive blow to the environment and a debt burden that would cripple poverty-riddled South Africa.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.nytimes.com/cwire/2010/04/09/09climatewire-south-africa-wins-375-billion-coal-loan-17887.html?pagewanted=2 | work=The New York Times | title=South Africa Wins $3.75 Billion Coal Loan | first=Lisa | last=Friedman | date=2010-04-09}}</ref>
